Sampling Distributions#

TODO

Central Limit Theorem#

The Central Limit Theorem is one of the most important theorems in statistics (if not mathematics). The Central Limit Theorem is what allows us to use the Normal Distribution to make inferences about the population

TODO

Motivation#

Consider a pop-quiz made up of two questions administered to a population of a 100 students. Suppose you conducted a census of how many questions each student got right on the pop-quiz. In other words, suppose you knew the probability distribution for the population was given by,

x

p(x)

0

0.20

1

0.30

2

0.50

It is important to keep in mind the meaning of this table. The right hand column represents the probability of selecting an individual with the left hand column number of answers correct. In other words, the probability a single randomly selected individual from the population got 0 answers correct is 0.20, or 20%. Similarly, the probability a single randomly selected individual from the population got 1 answer correct is 0.40, or 40%. Finally, the probability a single randomly selected individual from the population got both answers correct is again 0.50, or 50%. A graph of the density_function helps visualizes the situation,

(Source code, png, hires.png, pdf)

Since we are assuming we know the population distribution, we can see how sampling the population affects the value and distribution of the sample mean. This will provide insight into the more likely scenario of not knowing anything about the population and only having information about the sample. In other words, in what follows, the population distribution will be assumed to see what this implies about the sample mean. Then, the conclusions regarding the sample mean will be applied to scenarios where the population distribution is unknown.

Suppose a random sample of 2 students are drawn from this population with replacement. Recall “with replacement” means the same student may be observed more than once, since every student is put back into the population for subsequenct selections.

In drawing a sample of 2 students, an account must be taken of all possible ways this sample that might be drawn. Each student will have either gotten 2 answers correct, 1 answer correct or 0 answers correct. By the Generalized Counting Principle, the total number of possible 2 person samples that can be drawn from this population is,

\[3 \cdot 3 = 9\]

All possible samples Si are enumerated below in List Notation

\(S_1 = \{ 0, 0 \}\)

\(S_2 = \{ 0, 1 \}\)

\(S_3 = \{ 0, 2 \}\)

\(S_4 = \{ 1, 0 \}\)

\(S_5 = \{ 1, 1 \}\)

\(S_6 = \{ 1, 2 \}\)

\(S_7 = \{ 2, 0 \}\)

\(S_8 = \{ 2, 1 \}\)

\(S_9 = \{ 2, 2 \}\)

TODO

Sample Proportion#

TODO

Sampling Distribution for Sample Proportion

If \(\mathcal{X}_i \sim \text{Bern}(p)\) for \(i = 1, 2, ..., n\) and the following conditions for inference are met,

  1. \(n \cdot p \geq 10\)

  2. \(n \cdot (1 - p) \geq 10\)

The random variable, \(\hat{p} = \frac{\mathcal{X}_1 + \mathcal{X}_2 + ... + \mathcal{X}_n}{n}\) has the following distribution,

\[\hat{p} \sim \mathcal{N}(p, \sqrt{\frac{p \cdot (1 - p)}{n}})\]

TODO

Difference of Proportions#

TODO

Sampling Distribution for Difference of Sample Proportions

If \(\mathcal{X}_i \sim \text{Bern}(p_x)\) for \(i = 1, 2, ..., n_x\) and the following conditions for inference are met,

  1. \(n_x \cdot p_x \geq 10\)

  2. \(n_x \cdot (1 - p_x) \geq 10\)

And if \(\mathcal{Y}_i \sim \text{Bern}(p_y)\) for \(i = 1, 2, ..., n_y\) and the following conditions for inference are met,

  1. \(n_y \cdot p_y \geq 10\)

  2. \(n_y \cdot (1 - p_y) \geq 10\)

Then the random variable \(\hat{p}_x - \hat{p}_y\) has the following distribution,

\[\hat{p}_{x} - \hat{p}_y \sim \mathcal{N}(p_x - p_y, \sqrt{\frac{p_x \cdot (1 - p_x)}{n_x} + \frac{p_y \cdot (1 - p_y)}{n_y}} )\]

TODO

Sample Mean#

TODO

Known Standard Deviation#

TODO

Sampling Distribution for the Sample Mean, Known Standard Deviation, Version 1

If

  1. \(\mathcal{X}_i \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu, \sigma)\) for \(i = 1, 2, ..., n\)

And the following conditions for inference is met,

  1. \(n \geq 30\)

Then the random variable \(\bar{\mathcal{X}} = \frac{\mathcal{X}_1 + \mathcal{X}_2 + ... + \mathcal{X}_n}{n}\) has the following distribution,

\[\bar{\mathcal{X}} \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu, \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}})\]

TODO

Sampling Distribution for the Sample Mean

If

  1. \(\mathcal{X}_i \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu, \sigma)\) for \(i = 1, 2, ..., n\)

And the following conditions for inference is met,

  1. \(n \geq 30\)

Then the standardized value \(\mathcal{Z}\) of the random variable \(\bar{\mathcal{X}} = \frac{\mathcal{X}_1 + \mathcal{X}_2 + ... + \mathcal{X}_n}{n}\) has the following distribution,

\[\frac{\bar{X} - \mu}{ \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} \sim \mathcal{N}(0, 1)\]

TODO

Unknown Standard Deviation#

TODO

Distribution of Sample Mean, Standard Deviation Unknown

Let each \(\mathcal{X_i}\) for \(i = 1, 2, ..., n\) be selected from the same population. If \(n \geq 30\), then

\[\frac{ \bar{X} - \mu }{ \frac{s}{ \sqrt{n} } } \sim t(n-1)\]

Difference of Sample Means#

Known Standard Deviation#

TODO

Sampling Distribution for Difference of Sample Means, Standard Deviation Known

If

  1. \(\mathcal{X}_i \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu_x, \sigma_y)\) for \(i = 1, 2, ..., n_x\)

  2. \(\mathcal{Y}_i \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu_y, \sigma_x)\) for \(i = 1, 2, ..., n_y\)

And the following conditions for inference is met,

  1. \(min(n_1, n_2) \geq 30\)

Then the random variable \(\bar{\mathcal{X}} - \bar{\mathcal{Y}}\) has the following distribution,

\[\bar{\mathcal{X}} - \bar{\mathcal{Y}} \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu_x - \mu_y, \sqrt{ \frac{{\sigma_x}^2}{n_x} + \frac{{\sigma_y}^2}{n_y}})\]
